study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of a 12-week physical activity intervention, including home-based walking, on physical activity behavior, physical function, waist circumference, and quality of life in obese, socioculturally diverse endometrial cancer survivors.
results_summary: The intervention showed large effect sizes for improvements in the six-minute walk test, waist circumference, quality of life, and walking self-efficacy compared to the control group, with participants reporting walking 118±79 minutes per week at home.
population_specificity: Obese endometrial cancer survivors from Bronx, NY (38% non-Hispanic black, 38% Hispanic, 19% non-Hispanic white).

study_goal: To determine the efficacy of fast walking training plus a step activity monitoring program (FAST+SAM) compared to fast walking training alone (FAST) in improving walking endurance and activity in persons with chronic stroke.
results_summary: Both FAST and FAST+SAM improved walking outcomes, but FAST+SAM was superior for increasing 6-minute walk test distance. The FAST+SAM intervention was particularly effective for individuals with initially low levels of walking endurance and activity.
population_specificity: Individuals >6 months post-stroke (N=37).
effective_dosage: Walking training at fastest possible speed on treadmill (30min) and overground, 3 times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of symptomatic treatment (double elasticated bandage) versus immobilisation (below-knee walking cast) for fractures of the base of the fifth metatarsal, using patient-reported outcome measures (PROMs).
results_summary: Symptomatic treatment was found to be non-inferior to immobilisation at four weeks and six months based on the VAS-FA Score. The study concluded that immobilisation offers no significant advantage over symptomatic treatment for this type of fracture.
population_specificity: 60 patients with fractures of the base of the fifth metatarsal.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (treatment involved immobilisation or bandage, not a supplement).
study_duration: Four weeks of treatment, with follow-ups at three and six months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of the Safe Routes to School (SRTS) program on pedestrian and bicyclist injury risk in school-age children.
results_summary: The SRTS program was associated with a 23% reduction in pedestrian/bicyclist injury risk and a 20% reduction in fatality risk among school-age children compared to adults.
population_specificity: School-age children (5-19 years) and adults (30-64 years) in 18 U.S. states.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical results and 1-year survival of hemiarthroplasty (HA) for unstable intertrochanteric (IT) fractures versus displaced femoral neck (FN) fractures in elderly patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in perioperative results, postoperative complications, walking status, Harris hip score, or 1-year survival between HA for unstable IT fractures and HA for displaced FN fractures in elderly patients.
population_specificity: Elderly patients aged 75 years or older with unstable IT fractures (AO/OTA type 31-A2.2/3 and A3.3) or displaced FN fractures (Garden type 3 and 4).
study_duration: Follow-up at 6 months and 1 year post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to objectively assess the efficacy of electroacupuncture (EA) for improving gait disorders in Parkinson's disease (PD) patients using body-worn sensor technology.
results_summary: The study found that EA significantly improved gait parameters, including speed and stride length, in PD patients, with the most notable improvements during single-task and dual-task walking conditions. No significant changes were observed in the control group.
population_specificity: Fifteen Parkinson's disease patients with gait disorders.
effective_dosage: Three weekly EA treatments (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of high-frequency spinal cord stimulation (HF10 SCS) for treating chronic intractable pain, including its impact on functional outcomes like walking tolerance.
results_summary: The study found that HF10 SCS significantly reduced pain (50% mean reduction) and improved functional outcomes, including walking tolerance, with sustained effects at 6 months post-implant. Patients who had previously failed traditional SCS also reported positive outcomes.
population_specificity: 256 patients with chronic intractable pain of various etiologies, including back + leg, back only, head ± neck, and neck ± arm/shoulder pain.

study_goal: To compare long-term clinical and radiographic outcomes after ACL reconstruction using patellar tendon (PT) autografts versus hamstring tendon (HT) autografts.
results_summary: Minor differences were found between PT and HT autografts, with HT showing better pivot-shift test results but no significant differences in other laxity tests, patient-reported outcomes, or radiographic OA. Both groups showed more signs of OA in the reconstructed knee compared to the healthy contralateral knee.
population_specificity: 193 patients who underwent unilateral primary ACL reconstruction (PT: 61, HT: 86 at follow-up).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and safety of MILD versus epidural steroid injections (ESIs) in improving function and reducing pain for Medicare beneficiaries with lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS) and neurogenic claudication.
results_summary: At 1-year follow-up, MILD demonstrated statistically significant superiority over ESIs in improving function (ODI) and reducing pain (NPRS and ZCQ domains), with a 58.0% responder rate for MILD versus 27.1% for ESIs. Safety profiles were comparable between the two treatments.
population_specificity: Medicare beneficiaries with lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS), neurogenic claudication, and verified ligamentum flavum hypertrophy.
study_duration: 1-year follow-up (2-year data for MILD group only)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effects of a treadmill walking program on arterial blood oxygenation, maximum oxygen consumption, and maximum walking distance in healthy elderly people, comparing supervised short-term and unsupervised long-term outcomes.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in SaO2, VO2max, and MWD in the intervention group compared to baseline and the control group at 12, 30, and 48 weeks, with supervised intervention showing greater improvements than unsupervised.
population_specificity: Healthy elderly people (40 men and 40 women, aged not specified).
effective_dosage: Walking on a treadmill 3 times weekly for 48 weeks (first 12 weeks supervised, remaining 36 unsupervised).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of overground robotic walking training using the i-Walker on walking performance, balance, gait stability, and falls in patients with mild subacute stroke.
results_summary: The i-Walker group showed significant improvements in balance, walking speed (10-m test), endurance (6-min test), and gait stability, along with a reduced number of falls compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Patients with mild subacute stroke.
effective_dosage: Two daily 40-minute sessions, 5 days a week for 4 weeks (20 sessions with i-Walker, 20 sessions standard therapy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review evidence on exercise and physical activity as potential disease-modifying treatments for multiple sclerosis (MS), with a focus on walking outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that exercise and physical activity were associated with reduced relapse rates, slower mobility disability progression, decreased lesion volume, and improved neuroperformance, particularly in walking outcomes. The evidence suggests preliminary but positive effects on disease modification markers in MS.
population_specificity: Persons with multiple sclerosis (MS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine older and younger breast cancer patients' preferences for adjuvant therapies (chemotherapy and hormonal therapy) and their minimally required benefits in terms of disease-free survival.
results_summary: Older participants were less willing to accept adjuvant chemotherapy than younger participants, but no significant difference was found for hormonal therapy. Factors like marital status, geriatric conditions, and decision-making preferences influenced the required benefits for accepting chemotherapy.
population_specificity: Older (≥65 years) and younger (40-64 years) women with a first primary, invasive breast tumor.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of revascularization plus best medical therapy (including unsupervised exercise) versus best medical therapy alone on health-related quality of life and walking distance in patients with intermittent claudication.
results_summary: Revascularization combined with best medical therapy significantly improved health-related quality of life and intermittent claudication distance compared to best medical therapy alone, though maximum walking distance and 6-minute walk test results were similar between groups.
population_specificity: Patients with intermittent claudication due to iliac or femoropopliteal peripheral artery disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and evaluate quick, simple, and easy-to-use measures of walking ability for children and adolescents with cerebral palsy (CP), focusing on their clinical utility and psychometric properties.
results_summary: The study identified five measures (1-Minute Walk Test, Timed Up and Go Test, ABILOCO-Kids, Gillette Functional Assessment Questionnaire, and Functional Mobility Scale) that can be performed within 5 minutes with limited equipment and no examiner training. While reliability and validity evidence ranged from "limited" to "strong," evidence on measurement error and responsiveness was limited, potentially affecting their utility for tracking change over time.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with cerebral palsy (CP).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (assessment tools, not a dosage-based intervention).
study_duration: Not applicable (systematic review of existing measures).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of moderate-intensity versus high-intensity aerobic training combined with body mass-based resistance exercises on muscle hypertrophy and strength in older women.
results_summary: Both training groups showed significant increases in muscle thickness and knee extension strength, with greater improvements linked to lower baseline muscle thickness. Moderate-intensity aerobic training (walking at 55% peak oxygen uptake) was associated with improved aerobic capacity.
population_specificity: 12 untrained older women (mean age 60 ± 2 years).
effective_dosage: Walking at a speed equivalent to 55% peak oxygen uptake, combined with body mass-based resistance exercises (2 sets of 10 repetitions, 3 days/week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding whole body vibration training (WBV) to quadriceps and hamstring strengthening training (ST) improves functional activity, pain, quality of life, and muscle strength in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found that the ST + WBV group showed significant improvements in the 2-minute walking test (2MWT), muscle peak torque (MPT), total work (TW), and muscle power (MP) compared to the ST-only group. However, no significant differences were observed in pain, quality of life, TUGT, or 50FWT between the two groups.
population_specificity: 28 patients with knee osteoarthritis (13 in ST group, 15 in ST + WBV group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if treadmill walking combined with obstacle-crossing improves walking ability in ambulatory post-stroke patients.
results_summary: The experimental group showed significant improvements in the 6-minute walk test and Berg Balance Scale compared to the control group, but no significant differences were found in the 10-meter walk test, timed "Up & Go" test, or Activities-specific Balance Confidence scale. Both groups improved in all measures post-intervention.
population_specificity: Ambulatory post-stroke patients (29 subjects from a university hospital-based rehabilitation center).
effective_dosage: 30 minutes/day, 5 times/week of treadmill walking with obstacle-crossing (experimental group) or standard treadmill walking (control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of walking on body weight, BMI, and body fat percentage in perimenopausal and postmenopausal women through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found statistically significant reductions in BMI (-0.33 kg/m²), body weight (-1.14 kg), and body fat percentage (-2.36%) due to walking interventions. The results were consistent across studies with low heterogeneity.
population_specificity: Perimenopausal and postmenopausal women who were inactive at baseline.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a telephone-based goal-setting intervention on improving dietary and physical activity outcomes, including leisure time walking, in adults with type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular risk factors.
results_summary: The multiple-goal group showed a significant increase in leisure time walking, while the single-goal group did not demonstrate significant improvements in physical activity. The study suggests that a multiple-goal approach may be more effective for enhancing physical activity outcomes like walking.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese adults aged 40-75 years with type 2 diabetes and at least one additional cardiovascular disease risk factor.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether a sequential bilateral bronchoscopic lung volume reduction procedure could prolong clinical benefits in patients with heterogeneous emphysema who initially underwent unilateral treatment.
results_summary: The study found that a sequential bilateral procedure significantly improved respiratory function (e.g., forced expiratory volume, 6-minute walking test) in patients who lost benefits from the first treatment, with results maintained during follow-up. No significant differences were observed between bilateral and unilateral groups in most measured outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with bilateral heterogeneous emphysema who previously underwent unilateral bronchoscopic valve treatment.
study_duration: Follow-up duration not explicitly stated, but data spanned 4 years.

study_goal: To assess the effect of training general practitioners in optimizing drug treatment for newly detected heart failure on patient outcomes, including walking distance.
results_summary: Patients in the intervention group showed a longer walking distance in the six-minute walk test compared to the care-as-usual group, with mean differences of 28.0 meters for all-type HF, 28.2 meters for HFpEF, and 55.9 meters for HFrEF. No significant differences were found in medication uptake or general health status between groups.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older persons with a new heart failure diagnosis (HFrEF or HFpEF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify factors associated with institutionalization and mortality in elderly patients with hip fractures, including the role of walking ability.
results_summary: The study found that loss of autonomy in walking, along with age, cognitive status, and living alone, was associated with higher mortality and institutionalization rates in elderly hip fracture patients.
population_specificity: Elderly patients (aged 65+) with hip fractures, living in the community or nursing homes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a culturally tailored physical activity (PA) program, including walking, for improving PA behavior and psychosocial mediators among clergy.
results_summary: The intervention significantly reduced sedentary behavior, increased PA behavior, and improved self-efficacy and outcome expectations for PA among clergy. The culturally tailored program showed potential to influence both PA behavior and its psychosocial mediators.
population_specificity: Clergy (N = 44)

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to compare the safety and effectiveness of minimally invasive sacroiliac joint fusion (SIJF) using triangular titanium implants versus conservative management (CM) in patients with chronic sacroiliac joint (SIJ) pain.
results_summary: The study found that minimally invasive SIJF using triangular titanium implants was more effective than CM in relieving pain, reducing disability, improving patient function, and quality of life, with no significant difference in adverse events between the groups.
population_specificity: 103 adults with chronic SIJ pain at nine sites in four European countries.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (surgical intervention vs. conservative management).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding aerobic exercise (cycle ergometer) to conventional physiotherapy could maintain functional capacity, pulmonary function, and respiratory muscle strength in coronary artery bypass grafting patients.
results_summary: The intervention group maintained functional capacity (measured by 6-minute walking test), while the control group showed a significant decline. No significant differences were found in pulmonary function or respiratory muscle strength between groups.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing coronary artery bypass grafting (n=34, intervention group=19, control group=15).
effective_dosage: Not specified (additional aerobic exercise with cycle ergometer).
study_duration: From surgery to hospital discharge (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the tolerability and effectiveness of a side pole static ankle foot orthosis in preventing transverse-plane foot deformities in children with neurological disorders.
results_summary: The orthosis was well tolerated, with 84.8% of patients still wearing it daily after 4 years and a low discontinuation rate (14.7%). It effectively addressed foot deformities, with varus being the most common (66%) and equinus associated in 59.2% of cases.
population_specificity: Children with neurological disorders causing transverse-plane foot deformities in one or both feet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the validity and reliability of the 6-minute walk test (6MWT) and StepWatch Activity Monitoring (SAM) as outcome measures for Charcot-Marie-Tooth (CMT) disease.
results_summary: The study found that the 6MWT was highly correlated with previously used outcome measures, while SAM provided additional data that better correlated with quality of life measures, making it useful for future rehabilitation trials.
population_specificity: 168 CMT patients (104 with CMT1A, 27 with CMT1B, 37 with X-linked CMT) from Italian centers specializing in CMT care.

study_goal: To determine whether repeat exposure to force perturbations during treadmill training can induce long-term retention of improved step length and locomotor function in persons with spinal cord injury.
results_summary: Resistance training significantly increased step length after 6 weeks, while assistance training showed a non-significant trend. Functional gains did not differ significantly between groups, and resistance training may prolong retention of step length improvements.
population_specificity: Fourteen patients with spinal cord injury.
study_duration: 6 weeks of training, with follow-up at 8 weeks post-training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Kinesio taping improved functionality, pain, range of motion, and muscle strength in patients with knee osteoarthritis compared to placebo taping.
results_summary: Kinesio taping significantly reduced pain during activity and walking tasks compared to placebo, with improvements lasting up to 1 month. It also showed short-term benefits in night pain and knee-flexion range of motion, but no significant differences in muscle strength or other ROM measures.
population_specificity: 42 patients with knee osteoarthritis
effective_dosage: Not specified (application frequency: initial, third application, and 1-month follow-up)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the external validity of intervention studies focused on improving gait in individuals post-stroke, specifically examining exclusion criteria and ecological validity of the interventions.
results_summary: The review found that many studies had exclusive samples due to strict exclusion criteria, and half of the interventions were technologically elaborate. Titles/abstracts often did not accurately reflect the narrow populations studied, limiting the external validity of the findings.
population_specificity: Individuals post-stroke (acute, subacute, or chronic stages).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a postoperative assisted rehabilitation program in improving balance, gait, and general function in elderly patients after burr-hole drainage for chronic subdural hematoma.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in trunk control, standing balance, and neurological and ambulatory status at discharge, with 74.2% of previously ambulatory patients maintaining gait function. However, residual functional impairment limited discharge to home for many patients.
population_specificity: Thirty-five patients aged 65 or older who underwent burr-hole drainage for chronic subdural hematoma.
study_duration: Until hospital discharge (specific duration not stated).

study_goal: To assess the effects of corticosteroids on prolongation of walking ability, muscle strength, functional ability, and quality of life in Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD), including comparisons of different corticosteroids and regimens.
results_summary: Corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone, prednisolone, deflazacort) improved muscle strength and function in boys with DMD over six months to two years, with 0.75 mg/kg/day showing superior efficacy. Adverse effects like weight gain and behavioral changes were common but manageable, and weekend-only prednisone was as effective as daily prednisone in the short term.
population_specificity: Boys with a definite diagnosis of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD).
effective_dosage: 0.75 mg/kg/day prednisone or prednisolone; 0.9 mg/kg/day deflazacort; weekend-only prednisone at 5 mg/kg/weekend day.
study_duration: Ranged from six months to two years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and reliability of a comprehensive geriatric assessment (CGA-GOLD) in identifying broader needs, including mobility issues like difficulty walking, among older cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found that 14.9% of older cancer patients reported difficulty walking, highlighting mobility as a significant concern in this population. The CGA-GOLD questionnaire reliably identified higher-risk patients needing further intervention.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 65+ attending oncology services.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the biomechanical effects of walking after Scarf osteotomy versus first MTP joint arthrodesis, focusing on ground reaction forces and propulsion.
results_summary: Scarf osteotomy resulted in better restoration of propulsive function during walking, closely resembling the non-operated foot, while arthrodesis did not fully recover forefoot propulsive forces. Statistical analysis confirmed significant surgery and foot effects on vertical forces and anteroposterior impulse.
population_specificity: 19 patients who underwent Scarf osteotomy (mean age 50.3) and 18 who underwent first MTP joint arthrodesis (mean age 56.2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore whether there is an association between clinical balance measures (including walking tests) and fracture prediction obtained from FRAX®.
results_summary: The study found that individuals with high FRAX® values had poor outcomes in balance measures, with standing one leg eyes closed showing the strongest correlation. Combining FRAX® and balance measures may improve identification of high fall and fracture risk.
population_specificity: 82 participants (54 to 89 years, mean age 71.4, 77 female) with fall-related wrist fractures between 2008 and 2012.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a physiotherapy-supervised functional exercise program (including walking) between 12 and 18 weeks following total hip replacement (THR) compared to usual care.
results_summary: The study found that the functional exercise group showed significant improvements in WOMAC function and walking speed compared to the control group, but no significant difference in hip abductor strength.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent total hip replacement (THR).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the short- and long-term effects of supervised Nordic Walking (NW), supervised strength training (ST), and unsupervised home-based exercise (HBE) on functional performance in older adults with hip osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Nordic Walking (NW) showed greater improvements in functional performance compared to both ST and HBE at all follow-up time points, with superior benefits in vigorous physical activity and mental health. The NW group maintained significant improvements at 12 months, particularly in chair stand performance.
population_specificity: 60+-year-old persons (n = 152) with hip osteoarthritis not awaiting hip replacement.
effective_dosage: Supervised Nordic Walking sessions in a local park (frequency not specified).
study_duration: 4 months of intervention, with follow-ups at 2, 4, and 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether tocotrienol treatment could improve symptoms and IKBKAP expression in patients with familial dysautonomia (FD), including walking stability.
results_summary: Tocotrienol treatment initially increased IKBKAP expression but returned to baseline after 6 months. Clinical questionnaires reported improvements in walking stability and other symptoms, but no significant changes were observed in objective clinical measurements.
population_specificity: 32 FD patients (primarily Ashkenazi Jews), with 28 completing the study.
effective_dosage: Initial daily doses of 50 or 100 mg, doubled after 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a 3-month, email-based intervention grounded in social cognitive theory (SCT) to increase and maintain dog walking among dog owners.
results_summary: The intervention group accumulated significantly more weekly minutes of dog walking (58.4 more minutes on average) compared to the control group, with self-efficacy partially mediating the effect of social support on dog walking. The increase was maintained at a 12-month follow-up.
population_specificity: Dog owners (49 participants, 24 in the intervention group and 25 in the control group).
effective_dosage: Email messages (twice weekly for 4 weeks, then weekly for 8 weeks).
study_duration: 3 months (with follow-up assessments up to 12 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the use of total hip arthroplasty (THA) for displaced intracapsular hip fractures adhered to national guidelines and if systematic inequalities existed in its provision.
results_summary: The study found poor compliance with NICE guidelines for THA use, with disparities linked to age, cognitive status, socioeconomic deprivation, and weekend surgeries. A model with better explanatory power identified age and ambulation cutoffs not supported by NICE.
population_specificity: Patients aged ≥60 with non-pathological displaced intracapsular hip fractures in England, Wales, and Northern Ireland (2011–2015).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of external sensory cued therapy on activities of daily living (ADL) performance, including walking, in individuals with Parkinson's disease (PD).
results_summary: The meta-analysis showed statistically significant improvements in ADL performance after treatment and at follow-up, with all six included studies reporting positive findings for external sensory cues.
population_specificity: Individuals with Parkinson's disease (PD) across all stages of disease progression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of baroreflex activation therapy (BAT) on arterial stiffness in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF), including its impact on six-minute walking distance.
results_summary: BAT improved six-minute walking distance and clinical status (NYHA class, heart failure questionnaire score, and medication use) but did not significantly affect arterial stiffness or central blood pressure. The control group showed no significant changes in any measured variables.
population_specificity: 18 NYHA Class III HFrEF patients (9 receiving BAT, 9 on optimal medical management alone).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the practicality of using walking speed as a method to assess frailty in elderly hypertensives and its implications for antihypertensive treatment.
results_summary: The study suggests that walking speed can be a practical method to assess frailty, but it is not universally accepted. Frail elderly hypertensives may benefit less from antihypertensive treatment compared to robust older patients.
population_specificity: Frail and robust elderly hypertensives, including octogenarians.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the appropriate use of exercise testing, including submaximal walking tests, in cardiac rehabilitation settings to assess physiological responses, ischemia, arrhythmias, and overall stability.
results_summary: The study highlights the enduring value of exercise testing in cardiac rehabilitation, particularly for assessing dynamic physiological responses, ischemia, and symptoms relevant to exercise prescription and prognosis. It also notes the growing relevance of functional assessments, including walking tests, for clinically complex populations such as those with heart failure, valvular heart disease, and posttransplantation.
population_specificity: Patients in cardiac rehabilitation, including those with heart failure, valvular heart disease, posttransplantation, advanced age, multimorbidity, frailty, and obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize Japanese-language randomized controlled trials to evaluate the effectiveness of braces and orthoses for patients with knee osteoarthritis, particularly in improving pain and functional disability.
results_summary: Limited evidence supported short-lever elastic knee braces for improving pain and functional disability in specific outcomes, but no conclusive evidence was found for foot orthoses like laterally wedged insoles or medial arch support. The review highlighted methodological flaws in existing studies.
population_specificity: Patients with knee osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of a novel hip brace on hip rotation and abduction moment in individuals with hip osteoarthritis during walking.
results_summary: The brace significantly reduced peak hip abduction moment, adduction, and internal rotation angles during stance, with nine participants reporting immediate pain reduction. The findings suggest the brace may decrease compressive joint reaction forces at the femuroacetabular interface.
population_specificity: 14 subjects with unilateral symptomatic hip osteoarthritis
study_duration: Immediate effects assessed (no long-term duration mentioned)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the efficacy of repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) on improving physical function and motor signs, including walking performance, in people with Parkinson's disease (PD) over short- and long-term periods.
results_summary: The study found that rTMS significantly improved short- and long-term walking performance (Hedges' g: 0.61 and 0.89, respectively) and UPDRS III scores in PD sufferers, with subgroup analyses suggesting a more prominent effect for M1 stimulation.
population_specificity: People with Parkinson's disease (555 participants across 22 trials).
effective_dosage: Not specified (total stimulation pulses were associated with greater improvements).
study_duration: Short- and long-term (specific duration not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize data on strain mapping in the Achilles tendon, including its response to walking and other loading conditions.
results_summary: The study found that Achilles tendon strain has been investigated in various contexts, including walking, but only three studies examined the effect of tendinopathy on strain. Ultrasound was the most common imaging modality used, and recent findings highlight the importance of local strain distribution.
population_specificity: Elite and recreational athletes, with some focus on aging, hormonal changes, and weight.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine changes in balance, upper extremity motor capacity, and mobility in stroke patients during outpatient therapy.
results_summary: Patients showed small but consistent improvements in balance (BBS), upper extremity function (ARAT), and walking speed over the course of outpatient therapy, though individual trajectories varied. Starting therapy later or after inpatient rehabilitation was associated with lower initial scores.
population_specificity: Post-stroke patients (N=366) receiving outpatient rehabilitation.
study_duration: Duration varied by patient (measured in months of outpatient therapy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a respiratory filter could mitigate the adverse effects of air pollution on exercise capacity in heart failure patients.
results_summary: Diesel exhaust (DE) exposure reduced exercise capacity (VO2, 6mwt, O2Pulse) in HF patients, but filtration improved VO2 and O2Pulse. Filtration also increased VE and CO2-rebreathing in both groups.
population_specificity: 26 heart failure patients and 15 control volunteers.
study_duration: Single 6-minute session per condition (clean air, unfiltered DE, filtered DE).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether robot-assisted gait training enhances the antispastic effect of botulinum toxin type A on spastic equinus foot in chronic stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found no difference in spasticity reduction (measured by modified Ashworth and Tardieu scales) between groups, but a significant improvement in walking endurance (6-minute walking test) for the group receiving combined therapy.
population_specificity: 22 adult outpatients with spastic equinus due to chronic stroke.
effective_dosage: AbobotulinumtoxinA injection into spastic calf muscles; robot-assisted gait training (30 minutes/day for 5 days).
study_duration: 5 days of gait training, with evaluations before and one month after injection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether long-term wear of textured insoles could improve walking, foot sensation, and proprioception in people with multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: The study will assess the effects of textured insoles on gait parameters, foot sensation, and proprioception, with potential implications for mobility and independent living in people with multiple sclerosis. Results are pending as the study is prospective.
population_specificity: Adults with multiple sclerosis (Disease Steps score 1-4), ambulant over 100m, living in Brisbane, Australia.
effective_dosage: Not specified (textured or smooth insoles worn within participants' own footwear).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the evidence, methodological quality, and reporting of exergaming interventions in acute care settings, focusing on outcomes related to walking and other physical and cognitive measures.
results_summary: Exergaming showed benefits in energy expenditure, walking tests, balance, enjoyment, dyspnea, upper limb activity, cognitive performance, and hospital stay duration, but methodological quality was generally low with high risk of bias. Few studies adequately reported FITT components or adherence.
population_specificity: Patients in acute care settings (365 total participants across studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of the CHILE intervention on increasing physical activity, including walking, among preschool-aged children in rural Hispanic and American Indian communities.
results_summary: The study found a significant relative increase in overall physical activity in the intervention group compared to the control group, though walking specifically was not highlighted as significantly increased. Dancing showed the most notable improvement among the promoted activities.
population_specificity: Preschool-aged children from predominantly Hispanic or American Indian communities in rural areas.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare radiologic findings and clinical outcomes of accessory navicular syndrome (ANS) between athletes and nonathletes, focusing on treatment responses.
results_summary: Athletes with ANS showed poorer response to conservative treatment (6.9% improvement vs. 34% in nonathletes) and more severe radiologic abnormalities, suggesting early surgical intervention may be preferable for athletes.
population_specificity: 79 patients with ANS (29 athletes, 50 nonathletes).
study_duration: At least 6 months of conservative treatment for some patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 12 weeks of power training could improve voluntary muscle activation and gait speed in mobility-limited older adults.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in voluntary muscle activation (+6.2%), muscle strength (+13.4Nm), and gait speed (+0.12m/s) in the training group compared to controls, with improvements in muscle activation correlating with increased gait speed.
population_specificity: Mobility-limited older adults (mean age ~82 years) with usual gait speed <0.9m/s.
effective_dosage: 2 sessions per week of progressive high-load power training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding repeated botulinum toxin A (BTX-A) injections to conservative treatment was more effective than conservative treatment alone in reducing toe-walking in children over 24 months.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in toe-walking cessation between the BTX-A and conservative treatment groups at 24 months, though the BTX group appeared to achieve results earlier. No significant differences were observed in ankle range of movement or overall function between the groups.
population_specificity: Children aged 2-9 years with toe-walking.
effective_dosage: BTX-A injections repeated at 6-month intervals if needed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically analyze the effects of rhythmic auditory cueing on motor rehabilitation outcomes, such as gait and upper-extremity function, in stroke patients.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found large effect sizes for improvements in walking velocity, cadence, stride length, and Fugl-Meyer test scores with rhythmic auditory cueing. Subgroup analysis suggested possible differences in treatment effects based on cueing type and stroke stage, though these were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Stroke patients undergoing motor rehabilitation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the causes and treatments of plantar fasciitis, including the role of walking as a triggering factor.
results_summary: The study found that walking can trigger and aggravate plantar fasciitis, but supportive treatments like stretching, orthotics, and shock wave therapy can alleviate pain. Corticosteroid injections provide short-term relief but carry risks.
population_specificity: Individuals with plantar fasciitis, particularly those engaged in prolonged standing, walking, or running.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a combination of leucine, cholecalciferol, and medium-chain triglycerides (MCTs) could improve muscle strength and function, including walking speed, in frail elderly individuals.
results_summary: The study found that the LD + MCT group showed a 12.5% increase in walking speed, along with improvements in grip strength, leg function, and peak expiratory flow, while the LD + LCT and control groups showed no significant improvements.
population_specificity: 38 elderly nursing home residents (mean age 86.6 ± 4.8 years, 11 men and 27 women).
effective_dosage: Daily l-leucine (1.2 g), cholecalciferol (20 μg), and 6 g medium-chain triglycerides (MCTs) or long-chain triglycerides (LCTs), taken at dinner.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a therapeutic exercise protocol focused on the foot-ankle complex could reduce running-related injuries and improve biomechanics in long-distance runners.
results_summary: The study protocol was designed to assess the effects of an 8-week foot-ankle exercise program followed by 10 months of remote supervision, with outcomes including injury incidence, foot function, muscle strength, and biomechanical changes during walking and running. Final results were not provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: 111 healthy long-distance runners
effective_dosage: 1 directly supervised session and 3 remotely supervised sessions per week for 8 weeks, then 3 remote sessions per week for 10 months
study_duration: 12 months total (8 weeks intensive + 10 months maintenance)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a physical activity program, including walking, in improving or maintaining physical activity levels and fitness outcomes among older adults with intellectual disabilities.
results_summary: The program showed significant improvements in physical activity, muscle strength, blood pressure, cholesterol levels, and cognitive functioning, but no significant effects on balance, glucose, weight, waist circumference, walking speed, mobility, depression, or daily living activities.
population_specificity: Older adults (aged 43+) with mild-moderate intellectual disabilities.
effective_dosage: Three times a week for 8 months (group sessions of 8-10 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether umbilical cord blood-derived mononuclear cell (UCB-MNC) transplants combined with locomotor training could improve functional recovery, including walking ability, in patients with chronic complete spinal cord injury (SCI).
results_summary: The study found that UCB-MNC transplants and locomotor training improved walking ability (WISCI scores) and independence (SCIM scores) in some patients, with 15/20 patients able to walk 10 meters and 12/20 achieving independence in bladder and bowel management. However, motor and walking scores did not change in the Hong Kong cohort, suggesting variability in outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic complete spinal cord injury (C3-T11, averaging 7-13 years post-injury).
effective_dosage: Various dosages were tested, including 1.6 million cells (4-μl injections), 3.2 million cells (8-μl injections), 6.4 million cells (16-μl injections), and combinations with methylprednisolone (30 mg/kg) and lithium carbonate (750 mg/day).
interactions: Methylprednisolone and lithium carbonate were used in combination with UCB-MNCs in some groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of retro-walking and forward-walking on quadriceps muscle strength, pain, function, balance, and mobility in individuals with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results, as the study appears to be in progress or not yet concluded.
population_specificity: Sixty-nine participants with knee osteoarthritis recruited from an outpatient department.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate tendon metabolism (glucose uptake) and vascularization at 3, 6, and 12 months after Achilles tendon rupture during slow treadmill walking.
results_summary: The study found that repaired tendons had higher glucose uptake and vascularization than intact tendons up to 6 months post-injury, with metabolic activity remaining elevated beyond 12 months. A negative correlation was observed between tendon metabolism and patient-reported outcomes at 6 months.
population_specificity: 23 patients with surgically repaired Achilles tendon rupture (7 at 3 months, 7 at 6 months, 9 at 12 months post-surgery).
study_duration: Measurements taken at 3, 6, and 12 months post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the prevalence, clinical features, and prognostic impact of frailty (including slow walking speed) on outcomes after heart failure hospitalization in elderly patients.
results_summary: Slow walking speed was the most discriminative component of frailty, present in 89.2% of frail patients vs. 26% of non-frail patients. Frailty, including slow walking speed, was independently associated with higher risks of functional decline, mortality, and readmission.
population_specificity: Non-dependent elderly patients (≥70 years old) hospitalized for heart failure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of radiotherapy alone in improving motor and gait function in young men with malignant spinal cord compression (MSCC) from seminoma.
results_summary: All patients showed improved motor function after radiotherapy, with those unable to walk regaining walking ability. Local control and survival rates were high at one and two years.
population_specificity: Young men with MSCC due to vertebral lesions from metastatic seminoma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of whole-body vibration on heel strike, gait parameters, and ankle range of motion in children with idiopathic toe walking.
results_summary: The study found an immediate increase in heel contact and ankle range of motion post-intervention, but these improvements were not sustained 20 minutes after vibration. The gait improvement may be due to rapid increases in ankle range of motion or a neuromodulation response.
population_specificity: 15 children (10 males) with idiopathic toe walking, mean age 5.93 years.
study_duration: Single session with measurements taken up to 20 minutes post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of brisk walking versus Baduanjin exercise and usual physical activity on cognitive function and brain health in older adults with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).
results_summary: The study design includes a 24-week brisk walking intervention, but specific results regarding its effects on cognitive function or neuroimaging outcomes are not yet available (pre-results). The abstract suggests the study will measure cognitive domains and brain function changes over time.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).

study_goal: The researchers investigated associations between disease severity markers (including 6-minute walking distance) and long-term outcomes in patients with inoperable CTEPH or persistent/recurrent pulmonary hypertension receiving riociguat.
results_summary: The study found that 6-minute walking distance (6MWD) and NT-proBNP concentration were significantly associated with overall survival and clinical worsening-free survival in CTEPH patients. Riociguat was well tolerated, with no new safety signals identified.
population_specificity: Patients with inoperable CTEPH or persistent/recurrent pulmonary hypertension after pulmonary endarterectomy.
effective_dosage: Maximum dose of 2.5 mg riociguat three times per day.
study_duration: Most patients received riociguat for at least 2 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the long-term safety, efficacy, and prognostic value of riociguat in patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension, focusing on parameters like 6-minute walking distance (6MWD), WHO functional class, and NT-proBNP concentrations.
results_summary: The study found that riociguat was well tolerated, with improvements in 6MWD, WHO functional class, and NT-proBNP concentrations maintained after 2 years of treatment. Significant associations were noted between these efficacy parameters and overall survival at baseline and follow-up.
population_specificity: Patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension (396 participants, including those on riociguat monotherapy or combination therapy with endothelin receptor antagonists or prostanoids).
effective_dosage: Individually adjusted to a maximum dose of 2.5 mg three times a day.
study_duration: Most patients received at least 2 years of treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between fatigue and rate-pressure product (RPP) during submaximal walking in breast cancer survivors after a physical activity intervention.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significantly improved RPP during walking and reduced fatigue compared to usual care, with changes in RPP positively associated with fatigue reduction. No significant association was found between fatigue reduction and changes in aerobic fitness.
population_specificity: Post-primary treatment breast cancer survivors (152 participants).
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention included counseling/group discussions and supervised exercise sessions tapered to unsupervised exercise).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if energy consumption during walking differs among three clinical forms of MS (ataxic, spastic, ataxic-spastic) and healthy subjects, and to assess the association between PCI and EDSS.
results_summary: MS subjects had significantly slower walking speeds compared to healthy subjects, but no differences in resting or walking heart rates. Energy consumption increased due to reduced walking speed, with PCI correlating moderately with EDSS (r=0.65).
population_specificity: MS patients (EDSS>4) categorized into ataxic (n=16), spastic (n=15), and ataxic-spastic (n=14) groups, plus 13 healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the hemodynamic effects of postthrombotic obstruction in iliofemoral veins and identify pressure parameters differentiating affected and non-affected limbs during walking.
results_summary: Postthrombotic limbs showed a significant increase in common femoral vein pressure after walking (28.1 mmHg vs. 2.1 mmHg in controls), suggesting venous hypertension may explain venous claudication. Change in CFV pressure was the best discriminator between affected and non-affected limbs (AUC 0.94).
population_specificity: 22 participants (86.4% female, mean age 42.8) with unilateral iliofemoral postthrombotic obstruction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and efficacy of vagal nerve stimulation (VNS) in patients with chronic heart failure and reduced ejection fraction, including its impact on 6-minute walking distance.
results_summary: VNS did not reduce the rate of death or heart failure events but improved quality of life, functional class, and 6-minute walking distance compared to medical therapy alone. Left ventricular end-systolic volume index remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic heart failure, New York Heart Association class III symptoms, and ejection fraction ≤40%.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of current interventions to improve real-world walking for people with stroke and whether benefits are sustained.
results_summary: The study found a small but significant overall effect of interventions on real-world walking (SMD 0.29), with sustained benefits at >3-6 months (SMD 0.32). Interventions incorporating behavioral change techniques were more effective than exercise alone.
population_specificity: People with stroke

study_goal: To investigate the effect of motor imagery combined with rhythmic cueing on walking, fatigue, and quality of life in people with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: Both motor imagery interventions (music and metronome cues) significantly improved walking speed, distance, and perception compared to controls. Music-cued motor imagery was superior in improving health-related quality of life and physical fatigue, while both interventions improved cognitive fatigue.
population_specificity: Individuals with MS and Expanded Disability Status Scale scores of 1.5-4.5.
effective_dosage: 17 minutes of motor imagery, six times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to trace the historical development and efficacy of plaster-based treatments, including walking casts, for fracture management.
results_summary: The study highlights the evolution of plaster bandage techniques, leading to ambulatory treatment of fractures, with innovations like walking casts and open fracture care improving patient mobility and recovery.
population_specificity: Patients with fractures (historical context, no specific demographic details provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the pain-relieving effects of Lanconone® (1000 mg) and Ibuprofen (400 mg) during walking-induced knee joint pain.
results_summary: Both Lanconone® and Ibuprofen provided meaningful pain relief, with comparable onset times (65.31 vs. 60.82 minutes) and sustained relief for 6 hours. No adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: 72 subjects with mild to moderate knee joint pain on exertion (Pain Visual Analogue Scale >40 mm).
effective_dosage: Single dose of Lanconone® (1000 mg) or Ibuprofen (400 mg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if qualitative aspects of movement, specifically walking patterns, could improve the prediction of all-cause mortality in patients with advanced heart failure beyond established factors like the heart-failure survival score (HFSS).
results_summary: The study found that adding peak skewness (a measure of asymmetry in physical activity intensity) to the HFSS model significantly improved predictive ability for all-cause mortality, increasing the c-index from 0.71 to 0.74. This suggests that accelerometer-derived movement features can enhance prognostic accuracy in advanced heart failure patients.
population_specificity: 60 patients with advanced heart failure (NYHA III, peak VO2 <20 ml/kg, and LVEF <35%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the role and effectiveness of nurse-led interventions, including labyrinth walking, in improving coping and adaptation for incarcerated persons with mental health or substance use issues.
results_summary: The study found that nurse-led interventions such as labyrinth walking, CBT, and yoga were implemented to improve coping and adaptation in incarcerated persons, with seven of eight studies focusing on mental health or substance use issues.
population_specificity: Incarcerated persons with behavioral and psychological symptoms, particularly those with mental health or substance use issues.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of customized vestibular rehabilitation on balance, functional capacity, quality of life, and depression in patients with multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: The exercise group showed significant improvements in most balance, functional capacity, and quality of life parameters compared to the control group, with no significant changes observed in the control group. Customized vestibular rehabilitation was found to be effective for treating balance disorders in MS patients.
population_specificity: Forty patients diagnosed with multiple sclerosis, randomized into an exercise group (N=20) and a control group (N=20).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how the iTUG test sub-phases differentiate between mild- to moderate-stage Parkinson's disease (PD) patients and controls, and how these sub-phases correlate with cognitive function and health-related quality of life (HRQoL).
results_summary: The study found that PD patients took longer to complete the iTUG test, particularly during sit-to-walk, turning, and walk-to-sit phases, with fast-speed conditions better differentiating PD patients from controls. Some iTUG parameters correlated with executive function and HRQoL, but not with general cognitive function.
population_specificity: 28 mild- to moderate-stage PD patients (H&Y stage 1-3, medication OFF state) and 20 age-matched controls.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study involved movement assessment, not a supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy and safety of Shenmai injection (SMI) in improving functional outcomes for patients with chronic heart failure (CHF) and coronary artery disease (CAD).
results_summary: The study found that SMI significantly improved NYHA functional classification, 6-min walking distance, SF-36 score, and TCM syndrome score compared to placebo, with no apparent safety concerns.
population_specificity: Patients with CHF and CAD (n=240).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of limaprost and pregabalin, individually and in combination, on disability, leg pain, and walking distance in patients with lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS).
results_summary: The study found that limaprost was not inferior to pregabalin or the combination therapy in improving disability (ODI scores), leg pain (VAS scores), and walking distance (ICD). All three treatments showed significant improvements over time, with no additional benefit from combination therapy.
population_specificity: Patients with degenerative lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of transiliac osteotomy in correcting post-traumatic pelvic malunions, specifically focusing on limb-length discrepancy and walking ability.
results_summary: The study found that transiliac osteotomy improved walking ability in most patients, with 4 walking normally, 2 with a slight limp, and 2 requiring a cane. Pain relief was reported in most cases, and limb-lengthening was achieved.
population_specificity: Eight patients with post-traumatic pelvic malunions treated from 2006 to 2011.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) combined with Lokomat® gait training improves motor recovery and gait function in motor incomplete spinal cord injury (SCI) patients.
results_summary: The study found that tDCS combined with Lokomat® gait training was safe, with no reported side effects. Both anodal and sham tDCS groups showed significant improvement in lower extremity motor scores and gait function, but there were no significant differences between the two groups.
population_specificity: Motor incomplete spinal cord injury (SCI) patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects (benefits and harms) of different interventions, including ankle braces and rigid casts, for treating ankle fractures in children.
results_summary: The study found low-quality evidence that ankle braces led to quicker recovery of self-reported function at four weeks compared to rigid casts, with children preferring braces. Adverse events were minor but more frequent in brace groups due to improper sock use, while casts led to more unscheduled healthcare visits.
population_specificity: Children with clinically diagnosed low-risk ankle fractures, predominantly undisplaced Salter-Harris type I fractures of the distal fibula.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (interventions were ankle braces, rigid casts, or Tubigrip bandages).
study_duration: Varies by trial: 2 weeks (Trial A), 3 weeks (Trial B), or 2 weeks (third trial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if supervised progressive resistance training combined with home-based exercise was more effective than home-based exercise alone in improving leg extension power and gait parameters after unicompartmental knee arthroplasty.
results_summary: The study found that progressive resistance training combined with home-based exercise did not significantly outperform home-based exercise alone in improving leg extension power, walking speed, or KOOS scores. Both groups showed improvements in walking speed and KOOS scores, but no between-group differences were observed.
population_specificity: 55 patients who underwent unicompartmental knee arthroplasty.
effective_dosage: Progressive resistance training group: home-based exercise 5 days/week + progressive resistance training 2 days/week; control group: home-based exercise 7 days/week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of treadmill training on cognitive and motor performance in patients with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in cognitive performance (FAB-it) and motor function (6MWT) in the treadmill training group compared to the control group after one month. The results suggest treadmill training may effectively enhance cognitive and motor features in Parkinson's disease patients.
population_specificity: Seventeen patients with mild to moderate Parkinson's disease.
effective_dosage: Twelve 45-minute sessions, one session a day, three days a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of treatment on walking ability in multiple sclerosis patients with moderate to severe disability.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in walking performance, as measured by the Timed 25-Foot Walk test and the 12-Item Multiple Sclerosis Walking Scale, at 14 days and 3 months post-treatment. Adverse events were reported in 39.9% of patients.
population_specificity: Multiple sclerosis patients with an Expanded Disability Status Scale score between 4.0 and 7.0, normal kidney function, and no history of seizures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of walking (aerobic exercise) with other lifestyle interventions in reducing 10-year cardiovascular disease risk.
results_summary: Walking generally ranked second in reducing 10-year cardiovascular disease risk, with a maximum absolute risk reduction of 11.4% for high-risk individuals. It was found to be more effective than the Mediterranean diet and group therapy for smoking cessation but less effective than yoga.
population_specificity: Individuals with varying cardiovascular disease risk profiles, including high-risk individuals.

study_goal: To determine whether Padma 28 is effective, compared with placebo or other medications, in increasing pain-free and maximum walking distance for patients with intermittent claudication.
results_summary: Padma 28 significantly increased pain-free and maximum walking distances compared to placebo, but the clinical importance of these changes is unclear due to lack of quality of life data. Side effects were mild and not significantly different from placebo.
population_specificity: Patients with intermittent claudication (IC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of external beam radiation (EBR) in preventing restenosis after superficial femoral artery (SFA) stenting compared to a control group.
results_summary: The study found that a single 14 Gy dose of EBR did not prevent in-stent restenosis and was associated with higher stent thrombosis rates (33% vs. 13%) compared to the control group. There were no significant differences in total walking distances between the groups at 2 years.
population_specificity: 155 patients (46 women, 109 men; mean age 66 years, range 45-85 years) with SFA stenting.
effective_dosage: 0 Gy (control) or 14 Gy (EBR) administered once 24 hours after stenting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fitness training, including walking, reduces disability and improves outcomes like mobility, balance, and cognitive function in stroke survivors.
results_summary: Cardiorespiratory training involving walking improved walking speed, capacity, and balance, with some benefits persisting post-intervention. Mixed training also showed modest improvements in walking speed and capacity, but resistance training lacked sufficient data for conclusions.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential protective effects of low-impact sports like walking on the development or worsening of osteoarthritis (OA), particularly in comparison to high-impact sports.
results_summary: The study suggests that low-impact sports, including walking, may have a protective effect against the appearance or worsening of OA, contrasting with the higher incidence of OA observed in high-impact sports players. However, the long-term effects of continuing or ceasing such activities on early OA progression remain unclear.
population_specificity: Former high-impact sports players and the general population, with a focus on individuals at risk for or with early OA.

study_goal: To determine if gait training with a hybrid assistive limb (HAL) exoskeleton robotic device is safe and improves functional mobility and gait ability in subacute stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found significant increases in maximum walking speed, self-selected walking speed, and 2-minute walk test results. Secondary outcomes like balance and motor function also improved, though not significantly.
population_specificity: Eight patients with post-stroke hemiparesis whose walking impairment and gait recovery had plateaued.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore whether daily walking activity is associated with specific sub-regional hippocampal structural benefits in older adults at elevated risk for cognitive decline.
results_summary: The study found that daily walking activity was mainly associated with larger surface areas of the subiculum in women, independent of self-reported exercise. These results suggest that non-exercise, lifestyle physical activity may influence specific hippocampal sub-regions differently than exercise-related activity.
population_specificity: Nondemented, community-dwelling older adults at elevated sociodemographic risk for cognitive decline.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether adding calcitonin to epidural steroid and local anesthetic injections improves outcomes (pain, walking distance, disability) in patients with degenerative lumbar spinal canal stenosis compared to injections without calcitonin.
results_summary: Both groups showed comparable short-term benefits, but the calcitonin group maintained improvements in pain, walking distance, disability scores, and reduced analgesic use for up to one year. Calcitonin-enhanced injections were more effective long-term than steroid and anesthetic alone.
population_specificity: 132 patients with mild to moderate degenerative lumbar spinal canal stenosis.
effective_dosage: 50 international units of calcitonin added to epidural injections, administered twice, one week apart.
study_duration: Two injections one week apart, with follow-up for one year.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term efficacy and safety of Hymovis® in alleviating knee pain and improving function in patients with knee osteoarthritis, particularly focusing on walking-related pain.
results_summary: The study found that Hymovis® significantly improved pain during walking (WOMAC A1 score), stiffness, physical function, and overall quality of life (EQ-5D) in knee OA patients, with effects lasting up to one year. Radiological progression of OA was observed in 26% of patients, but 88% met responder criteria for therapy effectiveness.
population_specificity: Adults over 40 years old with clinically and radiologically confirmed knee osteoarthritis and knee pain.
effective_dosage: Two intra-articular injections (3 mL each, 8 mg/mL HYADD® 4) administered one week apart, repeated after 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the pain mechanisms modulated by etoricoxib in patients with painful knee osteoarthritis, focusing on its effects on pain biomarkers and clinical outcomes, including walking and stair climbing.
results_summary: Etoricoxib significantly improved pressure pain thresholds, temporal summation, and clinical outcomes such as pain scores, WOMAC, and walking/stair climbing tests. Nonresponders showed a significant association between increased facilitation of temporal summation and pain alleviation.
population_specificity: Patients with painful knee osteoarthritis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of a cognitive dual-task on the gait speed of community-dwelling older adults with no significant pathology affecting gait.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that adding a cognitive dual-task significantly reduced gait speed by 0.19 m/s (from 1.21 m/s to 1.02 m/s), with both mental-tracking and verbal-fluency tasks causing significant reductions. The study suggests dual-task walking may be valuable for clinical assessments in older adults.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults with no significant gait pathology.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine factors influencing survival in patients with severe pulmonary arterial hypertension treated with intravenous epoprostenol, including the impact of rapid dose escalation.
results_summary: The study found that rapid escalation of epoprostenol dose within the first year of treatment was associated with continuous reduction in mean pulmonary artery pressure and significantly improved 9.5-year survival (100% vs. 64%). Survivors also had longer 6-minute walking distances compared to non-survivors.
population_specificity: 46 patients with idiopathic and heritable pulmonary arterial hypertension in WHO functional class III or IV.
effective_dosage: Rapid increase group defined as ≥20 ng/kg/min at 3 months and ≥45 ng/kg/min at 1 year.
study_duration: Average follow-up period of 2100 days (~5.75 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between trunk control early after stroke and mobility performance, including gait characteristics derived from trunk accelerations.
results_summary: The study found that trunk motor impairment after stroke was significantly correlated with poor mobility performance and trunk instability during gait, particularly highlighting the importance of trunk coordination in walking speed and stability.
population_specificity: Fifteen patients with hemiparesis following stroke (median age 61 years, median time since stroke 9 days).
study_duration: Cross-sectional observational study (no intervention duration specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the long-term kinematic and kinetic outcomes of surgical treatment for idiopathic toe walking in children with gastrocnemius/soleus contractures.
results_summary: Surgical treatment significantly improved key kinematic and kinetic gait variables at 1 year post-operative, and these improvements were maintained at 5 years. Subjects reported high satisfaction, minimal pain, and unrestricted activities.
population_specificity: Children with idiopathic toe walking and gastrocnemius/soleus contractures.
study_duration: Follow-up at 1 year and >5 years post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an alternative setup to compare static and dynamic characteristics of pedicle screws at the bone-implant interface in lumbar osteoporotic cadavers, simulating in vivo walking conditions.
results_summary: The study found that subsidence at the screw head/tip was greatest during the first and last cycles until failure, with predominant patterns being pure rotation and toggling. Pull-out strength did not significantly differ between groups, but correlations were observed between pedicle angle, cyclic subsidence, and T-Score.
population_specificity: Human osteoporotic vertebrae (L1-L4) from cadavers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of structured physical activity, including walking, on respiratory outcomes in elderly adults with mobility limitations.
results_summary: Physical activity, including walking, did not significantly improve dyspnea severity, FEV1, or MIP compared to health education but was associated with a higher likelihood of respiratory hospitalization, particularly for exacerbation of obstructive airways disease. The increased hospitalization risk may be due to greater participant contact rather than direct adverse effects of physical activity.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling elderly adults aged 70-89 with mobility limitations (Short Physical Performance Battery scores <10).
effective_dosage: Goal of 150 minutes of walking per week, plus strength, flexibility, and balance training.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the efficacy and safety of inhaled iloprost in Japanese patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), not Walking.
results_summary: The study found that inhaled iloprost improved pulmonary vascular resistance and 6-minute walking distance in PAH patients, with common adverse events being headache and cough. No deaths or unexpected long-term safety issues were reported.
population_specificity: Japanese adults with PAH, either treatment-naïve or on endothelin receptor antagonists (ERAs) and/or phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitors (PDE5-Is), in NYHA/WHO functional class III/IV.
effective_dosage: 2.5 µg, increased to 5.0 µg if tolerated, 6-9 times daily.
study_duration: 12 weeks (with a 40-week extension phase for eligible patients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare physiological responses, energy cost of walking, perceived effort, and satisfaction between the 1M10 Adjust prosthetic foot and the SACH foot in hypomobile transtibial amputees.
results_summary: The study found no statistical differences in physiological responses between the two prosthetic feet, but the 1M10 Adjust significantly improved energy cost of walking, self-selected walking speed, perceived effort, and user satisfaction compared to the SACH foot.
population_specificity: Twenty hypomobile unilateral transtibial amputees (17 males, mean age 66.6 years), mostly classified as K-level 2.
study_duration: 30 days of use for the 1M10 Adjust before testing.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate clinical outcomes and biomechanical function of the foot and ankle in patients treated for atrophic-type congenital pseudarthrosis of the tibia (CPT) compared to healthy controls.
results_summary: Patients with CPT showed differences in biomechanical function, including slower walking speed, decreased dorsiflexion, and diminished ankle push-off power, but foot and ankle function was relatively well preserved. Clinical outcome scores were satisfactory, with no significant differences between subgroups.
population_specificity: 24 patients (mean age 19.1 years) treated for unilateral atrophic-type CPT and 24 healthy controls (mean age 19.6 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if there is a dose-response effect of exercise (including walking) on inflammation, fatigue, and activity levels in cancer survivors.
results_summary: The study found that exercise, including walking, significantly reduces fatigue and increases walking endurance in cancer survivors, with moderate-intensity aerobic exercise showing peak effects for improving endurance. No dose-response relationship was found between exercise and inflammation markers.
population_specificity: Adults diagnosed with cancer, regardless of specific diagnosis or treatment.
effective_dosage: Moderate-intensity aerobic exercise (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an inpatient exercise-based rehabilitation program, including walking, improves functional outcomes, symptoms, quality of life, and hospital stay duration more than a respiratory physiotherapy regimen in adults hospitalized for community-acquired pneumonia.
results_summary: The experimental group showed significantly greater improvements in functional outcomes (Glittre Activities of Daily Living test and incremental shuttle walk test), quality of life, dyspnea, and peripheral muscle strength compared to the control group. No differences were observed in lung function, C-reactive protein, or length of hospital stay.
population_specificity: Forty-nine adults hospitalized for community-acquired pneumonia.
effective_dosage: Walking at a controlled speed for 15 minutes as part of an 8-day physical training program.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the outcomes of intramedullary nailing versus Dynamic Hip Screw fixation for treating unstable intertrochanteric fractures, including walking recovery.
results_summary: Intramedullary nailing showed better outcomes in walking recovery and daily activities compared to Dynamic Hip Screw, with fewer non-union cases and shorter hospital stays. Radiologic and clinical parameters also favored intramedullary nailing.
population_specificity: 114 patients with unstable intertrochanteric fractures treated at Rasoul Akram hospital from 2011 to 2013.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and efficacy of Tafamidis in symptomatic ATTR patients, including its impact on neurological and cardiac function, particularly in non-Val30Met mutations and advanced disease stages.
results_summary: Tafamidis was safe and well-tolerated, with one-third of patients showing no significant disease progression over 36 months. However, 43% of subjects experienced functional progression, including worsened walking ability in 16 patients and higher NYHA scores in 12 patients. Neurological function worsened initially but slowed thereafter, and autonomic function remained stable in 33% of patients.
population_specificity: Symptomatic ATTR patients (61 participants, 42 males, mean age of onset 59 years, 28% Val30Met mutation, 18% advanced disease stage at entry).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Geriatric Interdisciplinary Home Rehabilitation could improve walking ability for older people with hip fracture compared to conventional care, and to assess postoperative hospital stay length.
results_summary: No significant differences in walking ability, use of walking devices, or gait speed were found between the intervention and control groups at 3- and 12-month follow-ups. The intervention group had a significantly shorter postoperative hospital stay (6 days shorter).
population_specificity: Older people (aged 70+) with hip fracture, including those with cognitive impairment, living in northern Sweden.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the association of calendar age and familial longevity with standard clinical and instrumented measures of physical performance, focusing on walking and chair stand tests in middle-aged to older adults.
results_summary: Higher calendar age was associated with slower walking speed and longer chair stand test duration, with instrumented measures showing similar effect sizes, particularly for gait stability and sit-to-stand transfers. No differences were observed between offspring of nonagenarian siblings and their partners.
population_specificity: Healthy middle-aged to older adults (mean age 65.3 years), including offspring of nonagenarian siblings and their partners.

study_goal: To examine the effects of radial extracorporeal shockwave therapy (rESWT) on plantarflexor spasticity after stroke.
